title: Stopping a sharp Alex McGough
text:
Stopping a sharp Alex McGough Aldo Giovanni Amato, agamato@dnj.com 8:51 p.m. CDT October 13, 2015 FIU Golden Panthers quarterback Alex McGough (12) will be a test for a Blue Raider secondary that's been inconsistent as of late. (Photo: Steve Mitchell-USA TODAY Sports) 1 CONNECT 1 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
MURFREESBORO — If MTSU plans on getting out of its three-game losing streak, the Blue Raiders will have to stop Florida International quarterback Alex McGough first. 
Halfway through the season, McGough has impressed with his decision-making and avoiding turnovers and has passed for 12 touchdowns and just two interceptions this season. 
McGough set career highs in last season’s matchup throwing for 231 yards and three touchdowns to go along with zero interceptions. 
“Their backs are heavily involved with the passing game, so we have to do a good job of tackling them once they catch it,” head coach Rick Stockstill said. “Their quarterback has done a nice job running their offense and eliminating mistakes. 
“He does a lot of good things, but that's one thing that sticks out the most to me." 
Safety Kevin Byard (20) is looking for his 18th career interception against FIU. (Photo: Jae S. Lee / The Tennessean) 
Safety Kevin Byard, who is one interception from breaking the school record for most in a career, knows the team will have to clean up mistakes and force turnovers against the Panthers. 
"He's a good quarterback, and he think he definitely has some good athletes that he can get the ball to. 
“He makes good decisions with the ball.” 
Last week against Western Kentucky, several Blue Raider defenders missed tackles in open space on the field, which led to big plays for the Hilltoppers. 
Defensive coordinator Tyrone Nix was not happy and said his squad will need to focus on fundamentals to help MTSU avoid a 2-5 record midway through the season. 
“We had a lot of small mistakes that led to big plays,” Nix said. “(McGough) is sharp with the ball, and he’s elusive also. 
“He doesn’t look like an elusive guy, but he’s hard to sack and runs the offense really well.” 
Nix said one of the areas MTSU will have to pay attention to Saturday is the middle of the field. 
Tight end Ya'Keem Griner is one of McGough’s favorite target’s with 20 receptions for 221 yards and two touchdowns on the year. 
“I think the tight end might be the best player on the offense,” Nix said. “They find different ways to get him the ball, and we’ll have to find out where he’s at on every play.” 
Reach Aldo Amato at 615-278-5109 and on Twitter @Aldo_ Amato 
Opponent: FIU
